image.altText: rachael brown majura primary p&c

props.synopsis: The ACT government changes its plans for a Canberra school expansion after data showed they expected fewer enrolments than had been predicted during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: Canberra school dismayed after $50 million expansion walked back

image.altText: A man with short brown hair wearing a red and blue checkered shirt speaks with his hands in front of a courthouse

props.synopsis: Mike Worsman was aged 12 when he was sexually abused in the 1990s in Canberra. He says the system's let him down.

title.children: 'Mere 16 months of peace': Survivor angered by abuser's sentence

image.altText: ANU signage with Genevieve Bell and Julie Bishop

props.synopsis: The prestige of the Australian National University is fast fading. It must now respond to explosive allegations.

title.children: How one of the world's most prestigious universities fell from grace

image.altText: New ACT number plate

props.synopsis: Canberra drivers to be refunded after toll operators charge for trips made by motorists with duplicate number plates.

title.children: Full refunds promised after toll charges for trips never taken

image.altText: A large building with a lot of windows against a clear sky.

props.synopsis: Millions of irreplaceable biodiversity specimens are re-homed at a new CSIRO facility in Canberra as its chief executive speaks for the first time about plans for change at the organisation.

title.children: CSIRO opens $90 million 'cutting edge' research facility

image.altText: Max and berts burnt

props.synopsis: Two heritage huts in the Namadgi National Park will not be rebuilt in an ACT government backflip, which experts say goes against heritage guidance and has left family and friends involved feeling betrayed.

title.children: 'Like a gravestone': The heritage huts that won't rise again

image.altText: A close up of a high school student.

props.synopsis: More than 30 ACT schools will have better access to period products with the expansion of an ACT government pilot program.

title.children: Student's fight to end period poverty brings free pads into more schools

image.altText: Julie Bishop stands in a conference room smiling

props.synopsis: ACT independent Senator David Pocock says he is concerned the issues facing the Australian National University are affecting its staff and students and calls for more transparency.

title.children: Bishop should stand aside from ANU role amid bullying claim, senator says

image.altText: A golden and black-furred rat with a white-tipped tail walks up a log with a fish in its mouth.

props.synopsis: You've told us loud and clear. It's finally time to announce Australia's most underrated animal for National Science Week. Is it the palm cockatoo? The dugong? Find out here.

title.children: Rakali beats palm cockatoo and cuttlefish to be crowned Australia's most underrated animal

image.altText: An aerial shot of suburban homes stretching into the distance.

props.synopsis: As industry leaders and the federal government prepare for next week's economic summit, two economists have started a national conversation by arguing that, to make Australia's tax system fairer, we should consider taxing home owner-occupancy. Here's what that means.

title.children: 'Imputed rent' and what it could mean for a fairer Australia

image.altText: A man plays with his earring while looking at something out of shot

props.synopsis: Aamin Khan says audiences downloading his films illegally have helped grow his popularity far beyond India's borders, while a technological revolution is helping pave a way forward for domestic fans.

title.children: A Bollywood legend thanks piracy and embraces $2 films

image.altText: David Stratton (for VT column)

props.synopsis: I write this to remember David and his incomparable contribution to Australian and world cinema, but also to implore myself and anyone else reading this: don't wait.

title.children: David Stratton reminds us not to wait to share the magic of cinema

image.altText: A 4WD car with 'help' spelt out in yellow tape on its boot.

props.synopsis: When Caleb Humphries's car broke down on the Nullarbor Plain, he spent two days watching cars drive past him and hoping someone would stop, until help was sent from more than 1,200 kilometres away.

title.children: Stranded Nullarbor driver watches cars pass him by for two days

image.altText: A composite image showing six book covers on a peach background

props.synopsis: Darren McCallum's daughter inspired him to write his first book for young children, The Wobbly Bike, which is among the winners of the 2025 CBCA Book of the Year awards.

title.children: Darwin tradie wins coveted award for a picture book about his daughter

image.altText: Richard Fidler and Sarah Kanowski sit on a radio panel smiling

props.synopsis: Over the course of two decades, Richard Fidler and Sarah Kanowski have enthralled millions, telling the remarkable stories of more than 3,200 guests. We asked listeners to share which Conversations guests have stayed with them long after the mic was turned off.

title.children: Listeners find stories of 'resilience and joy' in 20 years of Conversations

image.altText: Collins and Richard Marles stand side by side with Australian and NZ flags behind them.

props.synopsis: New Zealand's defence minister says the United States has carried the burden on defence for countries like Australia and her own, as the White House pressures the Albanese government to lift defence spending.

title.children: NZ defence minister sympathises with Trump's push to lift defence spending

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.5 per cent to a record high of 8,917.1 points, heading for its second straight weekly gain on Friday, and getting closer to breaking the 9000 barrier. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX hits record high, heading for 9000

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australians falling behind on mortgage payments: ANZ
What's on the agenda for next week's economic reform roundtable?
ASX hits record high, heading for 9000

image.altText: Harry Grant runs into Moses Leota as Nathan Cleary lines up a field goal in a Melbourne Storm-Penrith Panthers NRL game.

props.synopsis: Penrith captain Nathan Cleary says Storm captain Harry Grant "played for" a penalty as Cleary slotted a potentially game-winning field goal only for referee Ashley Klein to call it back late in their NRL showdown.

title.children: 'Why put them there?': The NRL warning Penrith failed to heed

image.altText: A muscular man wearing a backpack and black T-shirt and cap stands on a cliff edge.

props.synopsis: A security contractor held a senior role in what a US legal service says is an "anti-government extremist group" linked to the hard right. Now he works on an Israel- and US-backed humanitarian aid project in Gaza.

title.children: Fears a mysterious Gaza aid agency 'not all it seems to be'

image.altText: Five police officers at a crime scene at Sydney airport food court, with plants on either side.

props.synopsis: NSW Police allege the man accused of creating a disturbance at Sydney Airport assaulted train commuters 24 hours after being released on bail.

title.children: Man charged with separate assaults 24 hours after Sydney Airport incident

image.altText: A man and a woman in green and gold tracksuit tops fold their arms and look down at the camera.

props.synopsis: Sickness ruled their childhoods, but Emma, Jacob and their parents weren't giving up. Now, thanks to transplants, the duo are representing Australia at the World Transplant Games.

title.children: These siblings weren't sure they'd live past 30 years old, now they're representing Australia

image.altText: Melbourne Storm player Marion Seve runs with the ball while wearing goggles in an NRL game against Penrith Panthers.

props.synopsis: Marion Seve sported protective goggles in his return to the NRL on Thursday after a "traumatic" eye injury in June almost blinded him.

title.children: Storm battler sports NRL-first goggles to keep playing despite 'traumatic' eye injury

image.altText: Students in the classroom at Mistake Creek State School.

props.synopsis: There's a bunch of factors behind a persistent divide in educational levels of urban and regional students. Teacher shortages are one part of the problem.

title.children: The city-country education divide driven by 'wicked policy problem'

image.altText: A woman sits at a laptop with her dog next to her.

props.synopsis: Depression, cancer, sleep apnoea and migraines are among the leading health burdens on our workforce and it's costing Australia billions of dollars in lost work and lowered productivity, new research reveals.

title.children: Depression, breast cancer and migraines are costing the economy billions

image.altText: Man and woman smiling holding two young boys.

props.synopsis: Jake Parker has been diagnosed with lymphoma for a third time. A stem cell transplant gives him the best chance of seeing his little boys grow up, but he doesn't match any Australian donors.

title.children: Qld dad battling third cancer can't find stem cell donor in Australia

image.altText: White power drug, sprinkled on reflective surface, with ziplock plastic bag.

props.synopsis: The latest wastewater survey reveals Australians have consumed record amounts of meth, cocaine and heroin.

title.children: Australia's meth, cocaine, MDMA and heroin use up by 34 per cent

image.altText: A drone view of school buildings surrounded by suburban streets.

props.synopsis: The Friends' School in Hobart — the world's largest Quaker school — says the weapons sponsorships do not align with the school's peaceful philosophy.

title.children: World's largest Quaker school boycotts weapons-sponsored STEM programs

image.altText: Jim Chamers speaks at a press conference inside Parliament House

props.synopsis: One observer describes next week's economic roundtable this way: "Chalmers has opened a can of worms — and everybody has got a worm."

title.children: Can Jim Chalmers reap a healthy crop with the help of his big worm farm?

image.altText: A woman and man with sunglasses.

props.synopsis: Emma Lovell died in December 2022, after being stabbed by the juvenile — now aged 20 — on her front lawn in North Lakes.

title.children: Sentence for juvenile who murdered Emma Lovell reduced on appeal

image.altText: Portrait of Princess Anne in a black ceremonial hat and gold epaulettes laughs

props.synopsis: As Princess Anne celebrates her 75th birthday those who have worked beside her reveal her no-nonsense approach to a privileged life.

title.children: Princess Anne takes a no-nonsense approach to turning 75

image.altText: An Australian cyclist reacts after the finish of an Olympic event on the track.

props.synopsis: A year after winning Olympic silver for Australia, Matthew Richardson has become the fastest cyclist of all-time — in the colours of Great Britain.

title.children: Aussie defector Richardson becomes fastest track cyclist of all-time

image.altText: A young white girl with long brown hair pulled back into pig tails. She is vision-impaired, wearing glasses and a school uniform

props.synopsis: Japanese is one of the most studied languages for high schoolers — but few do it like Jacinta McIntyre. The 14-year-old is blind and learning the language through braille.

title.children: Many Aussies learn Japanese at school — but probably not like this

image.altText: The exterior of a Coles supermarket at night, with the name "coles" on light-up letters.

props.synopsis: Cleaning up even a small amount of a $110 billion "red tape burden" could deliver billions in savings, the Business Council of Australia says, ahead of next week's economic reform round table.

title.children: Business Council calls out $110bn 'red tape burden', saying clean-up could save billions

image.altText: A man in front of a microphone wearing headphones making expressions with his hands and face

props.synopsis: The Productivity Commission says artificial intelligence could offer a $116 billion shot in the arm to Australia's economy. But for people like voice actor Colin Cassidy, that means a disruption to their daily work.

title.children: Voice actors are already losing work to an AI disruption expected to reach everything

image.altText: A child wearing traditional black clothing and head covering, wearing sunglasses, holding a paddle.

props.synopsis: Rayyan Arkan Dikha became a social media sensation for his spontaneous dance atop a racing boat. Now, there are warnings of impersonators trying to profit off his fame.

title.children: Viral 'aura farming' boy drew global attention, but not all of it was welcome
